Detailed Description

template<typename T, size_t N>
class Tensor< T, N >

Forward declaration for autograd.

Multi-dimensional array with GPU, BLAS, and autograd support.

Template Parameters
TData type (float, double, int, etc.)
NNumber of dimensions

A powerful tensor class supporting:

  • Arbitrary dimensions (compile-time fixed)
  • GPU acceleration (CUDA)
  • Optimized BLAS operations
  • Automatic differentiation (autograd)
  • Element-wise operations with broadcasting
  • Mathematical functions (exp, log, sin, etc.)
  • Statistical operations (mean, variance, correlation)
  • Linear algebra operations
  • Tensor views and slicing

Memory Layout

Data is stored in row-major order in a flat array. Strides are computed automatically to enable efficient multi-dimensional indexing.

Automatic Differentiation

When requires_grad is true, the tensor participates in gradient computation. Operations build a computational graph that can be traversed via backward().

Example Usage

// Create a 2x3 matrix
Tensor<float, 2> A({2, 3});
A.fill(1.0f);
// Element-wise operations
auto B = A + 2.0f;
auto C = A * B;
// With autograd
Tensor<float, 1> x({10}, true, true); // GPU=true, requires_grad=true
auto y = x.exp().sum();
y.backward();
auto gradients = x.grad(); // Get computed gradients

◆ backend()

inline

Get the backend being used by this tensor.

Returns
The computational backend (GPU, BLAS, or CPU)

Returns the actual backend that will be used for operations on this tensor. The backend is selected at tensor creation time based on availability:

  • GPU: if compiled with USE_GPU, GPU is available, and use_gpu flag is true
  • BLAS: if compiled with USE_BLAS and GPU is not used
  • CPU: fallback when neither GPU nor BLAS is available

◆ backward()

template<typename T, size_t N>
std::optional< TensorError > Tensor< T, N >::backward ( const Tensor< T, N > * gradient = nullptr)
inline

Perform backward pass to compute gradients (autograd).

Computes gradients of this tensor with respect to leaf tensors by traversing the computational graph backwards.

Parameters
gradientOptional gradient tensor to start backpropagation. If nullptr, assumes this is a scalar with gradient 1.
Returns
std::nullopt on success, TensorError::InvalidArgument on error
Note
For scalar tensors (total_size() == 1), can be called without arguments.
For non-scalar tensors, must provide a gradient tensor.
Returns error if tensor doesn't require gradients
Returns error if called on non-scalar without gradient argument

Usage Example

// Scalar loss - no gradient needed
Tensor<float, 1> loss({1}, true, true);
loss.backward();
// Non-scalar - gradient required
Tensor<float, 2> output({3, 4}, true, true);
Tensor<float, 2> grad({3, 4});
grad.fill(1.0f);
output.backward(&grad);
Tensor::grad

std::nullopt on success, or TensorError on failure

◆ broadcast_to()

template<typename T, size_t N>
template<size_t M>
auto Tensor< T, N >::broadcast_to ( const TensorIndices< M > & target_shape) const->std::variant< Tensor< T, M >, TensorError >
inline

Broadcast this tensor to a new shape.

Template Parameters
MThe number of dimensions in target shape
Parameters
target_shapeThe target shape to broadcast to
Returns
A variant containing the broadcast tensor or an error

Broadcasting rules (NumPy-compatible):

  • Prepend dimensions of size 1 if needed
  • For each dimension, sizes must either match or one must be 1
  • Dimensions of size 1 are "stretched" to match the target

Example:

Tensor<float, 1> x({3});
auto result = x.broadcast_to<2>({4, 3}); // Shape (3,) -> (4, 3)

template<typename T, size_t N>
template<size_t M = N>
std::enable_if< M==1, TensorResult< Tensor< T, 1 > > >::type Tensor< T, N >::cross ( const Tensor< T, 1 > & other) const
inline

Cross product for 3D vectors. Computes the cross product of two 3D vectors: result = this other. The cross product is perpendicular to both input vectors and follows the right-hand rule.

Formula: If a = [a1, a2, a3] and b = [b1, b2, b3], then a b = [a2*b3 - a3*b2, a3*b1 - a1*b3, a1*b2 - a2*b1]

Parameters
otherThe other 3D vector to compute cross product with.
Returns
A variant containing either a new 3D tensor with the result or an error.
// Create two 3D vectors
Tensor<float, 1> a({3});
a[{0}] = 1.0f; a[{1}] = 0.0f; a[{2}] = 0.0f; // [1, 0, 0]
Tensor<float, 1> b({3});
b[{0}] = 0.0f; b[{1}] = 1.0f; b[{2}] = 0.0f; // [0, 1, 0]
// Compute cross product
auto result_var = a.cross(b);
if (std::holds_alternative<Tensor<float, 1>>(result_var)) {
auto& result = std::get<Tensor<float, 1>>(result_var);
// result = [0, 0, 1] (perpendicular to both a and b)
}

std::enable_if<(M >=3), TensorResult< Tensor< T, N+P-2 > > >::type Tensor< T, N >::dot ( const Tensor< T, P > & other) const
inline

Generalized dot product for N-D tensors (N >= 3). Performs tensor contraction over the last axis of this tensor and the first axis of the other tensor. For tensors A with shape (..., k) and B with shape (k, ...), the result has shape (...A[:-1], ...B[1:]). Uses GPU acceleration if available, otherwise uses parallel CPU execution.

Example: A(2,3,4) B(4,5,6) = C(2,3,5,6)

Parameters
otherThe other N-D tensor to contract with.
Returns
A variant containing either a new tensor with the result or an error.

Log-softmax operation (numerically stable). log_softmax(x) = log(softmax(x)) = x - log(sum(exp(x)))

◆ matmul()

template<typename T, size_t N>
template<size_t M = N>
std::enable_if< M==2, TensorResult< Tensor< T, 2 > > >::type Tensor< T, N >::matmul ( const Tensor< T, 2 > & other) const
inline

Matrix multiplication with autograd support (matmul).

Performs standard matrix multiplication: A(m,n) @ B(n,p) = C(m,p)

This is the fundamental operation for neural network layers. Uses optimized implementations (BLAS/GPU) when available. Supports automatic differentiation for training neural networks.

Template Parameters
MTemplate parameter ensuring N==2 (2D tensors only)
Parameters
otherThe tensor to multiply with (must have compatible dimensions)
Returns
Result tensor or TensorError::DimensionMismatch if incompatible

Example

// Linear layer: output = input @ weights
Tensor<float, 2> input({32, 784}, true, true); // batch=32, features=784
Tensor<float, 2> weights({784, 128}, true, true); // 784 -> 128 hidden units
auto output_result = input.matmul(weights);
if (std::holds_alternative<Tensor<float, 2>>(output_result)) {
auto& output = std::get<Tensor<float, 2>>(output_result);
// output shape: (32, 128)
}
// Full neural network layer with bias:
auto hidden = input.matmul(W1) + b1; // Broadcasting b1
auto activated = std::get<Tensor<float, 2>>(hidden).relu();
// Multi-layer network with autograd:
auto h1_result = input.matmul(W1);
auto& h1 = std::get<Tensor<float, 2>>(h1_result);
auto h1_act = (h1 + b1).relu();
auto h2_result = h1_act.matmul(W2);
auto& h2 = std::get<Tensor<float, 2>>(h2_result);
auto output = h2 + b2;
// Compute gradients:
auto loss = loss::mse_loss(output, targets);
loss.backward();
// Now W1.grad(), W2.grad(), etc. contain gradients

3784 }

942 other_ptr->grad_->data_[i] += grad.data_[i];
943 }
944
945 if (!other_ptr->is_leaf_ && !other_ptr->backward_funcs_.empty()) {
946 for (auto& func : other_ptr->backward_funcs_) {
947 func(*other_ptr->grad_);
948 }
949 }
950 }
951 });
952 }
953
954 return result;
955 }
956
957 // Try broadcasting
958 std::string error_msg;
959 if (!are_broadcastable(dims_, other.dims_, &error_msg)) {
960 return TensorError::DimensionMismatch;
961 }
962
963 // Determine broadcast shape
964 TensorIndices<N> broadcast_shape = dims_;
965 for (size_t i = 0; i < N; ++i) {
966 broadcast_shape[i] = std::max(dims_[i], other.dims_[i]);
967 }
968
969 // Create result with broadcast shape
970 bool track_grad = requires_grad_ || other.requires_grad_;
971 Tensor<T, N> result(broadcast_shape, use_gpu_, track_grad);
972 result.is_leaf_ = false;
973
974 // Perform broadcasted addition
975 size_t total = result.total_size();
976 for (size_t i = 0; i < total; ++i) {
977 TensorIndices<N> coords;
978 size_t idx = i;
979 for (size_t d = N; d > 0; --d) {
980 coords[d - 1] = idx % broadcast_shape[d - 1];
981 idx /= broadcast_shape[d - 1];
982 }
983
984 // Map to source indices
985 size_t self_idx = 0, other_idx = 0;
986 size_t self_stride = 1, other_stride = 1;
987 for (size_t d = N; d > 0; --d) {
988 size_t dim = d - 1;
989 size_t self_coord = (dims_[dim] == 1) ? 0 : coords[dim];
990 size_t other_coord = (other.dims_[dim] == 1) ? 0 : coords[dim];
991
992 if (dim + 1 < N) {
993 self_stride *= dims_[dim + 1];
994 other_stride *= other.dims_[dim + 1];
995 }
996
997 self_idx += self_coord * self_stride;
998 other_idx += other_coord * other_stride;
999 }
1000
1001 result.data_[i] = data_[self_idx] + other.data_[other_idx];
1002 }
1003
1004 // Setup backward pass
1005 if (track_grad) {
1006 // Capture pointers to input tensors
1007 Tensor<T, N>* self_ptr = const_cast<Tensor<T, N>*>(this);
1008 Tensor<T, N>* other_ptr = const_cast<Tensor<T, N>*>(&other);
1009
1010 result.register_backward([self_ptr, other_ptr](const Tensor<T, N>& grad) {
1011 // Gradient of addition: d/dx(x+y) = 1, d/dy(x+y) = 1
1012 if (self_ptr->requires_grad_) {
1013 if (!self_ptr->grad_) {
1014 self_ptr->grad_ = std::make_unique<Tensor<T, N>>(self_ptr->dims_, self_ptr->use_gpu_, false);
1015 self_ptr->grad_->fill(T(0));
1016 }
1017 size_t total = self_ptr->total_size();
1018 for (size_t i = 0; i < total; ++i) {
1019 self_ptr->grad_->data_[i] += grad.data_[i];
1020 }
1021
1022 // If self is not a leaf, propagate gradients further
1023 if (!self_ptr->is_leaf_ && !self_ptr->backward_funcs_.empty()) {
1024 for (auto& func : self_ptr->backward_funcs_) {
1025 func(*self_ptr->grad_);
1026 }
1027 }
1028 }
1029
1030 if (other_ptr->requires_grad_) {
1031 if (!other_ptr->grad_) {
1032 other_ptr->grad_ = std::make_unique<Tensor<T, N>>(other_ptr->dims_, other_ptr->use_gpu_, false);
1033 other_ptr->grad_->fill(T(0));
1034 }
1035 size_t total = other_ptr->total_size();
1036 for (size_t i = 0; i < total; ++i) {
1037 other_ptr->grad_->data_[i] += grad.data_[i];
1038 }
1039
1040 // If other is not a leaf, propagate gradients further
1041 if (!other_ptr->is_leaf_ && !other_ptr->backward_funcs_.empty()) {
1042 for (auto& func : other_ptr->backward_funcs_) {
1043 func(*other_ptr->grad_);
1044 }
1045 }
1046 }
1047 });
1048 }
1049
1050 return result;
1051 }

// x.grad() contains 3*x

◆ relu()

template<typename T, size_t N>
Tensor< T, N > Tensor< T, N >::relu ( ) const
inline

Apply ReLU (Rectified Linear Unit) to all elements (creates new tensor).

Computes ReLU(x) = max(0, x) for each element. Most widely used activation function in deep learning due to its simplicity and effectiveness in preventing vanishing gradients.

Properties:

  • Non-linearity without saturation for positive values
  • Sparse activation (outputs 0 for negative inputs)
  • Computationally efficient

Supports automatic differentiation.

Returns
A new tensor with ReLU(x) applied to all elements

Example

// Hidden layer in neural network
Tensor<float, 2> hidden({32, 128}, true, true);
auto activated = hidden.relu(); // Apply ReLU activation
// Full network layer example:
auto layer1 = (input.matmul(W1) + b1).relu();
auto layer2 = (layer1.matmul(W2) + b2).relu();
auto output = layer2.matmul(W3) + b3;
// With autograd:
auto loss = loss::mse_loss(output, target);
loss.backward(); // Gradients flow through ReLU layers

◆ sigmoid()

template<typename T, size_t N>
Tensor< T, N > Tensor< T, N >::sigmoid ( ) const
inline

Apply sigmoid function to all elements (creates new tensor).

Computes sigmoid(x) = 1 / (1 + exp(-x)) for each element. Commonly used as activation function in neural networks, especially for binary classification in output layers.

Range: (0, 1) - useful for representing probabilities. Supports automatic differentiation.

Returns
A new tensor with sigmoid(x) applied to all elements

Example

// Binary classification output layer
Tensor<float, 2> logits({32, 1}, true, true); // batch_size=32
auto probs = logits.sigmoid(); // Convert to probabilities in (0, 1)
// With autograd:
auto loss = loss::binary_cross_entropy(probs, targets);
loss.backward(); // Computes gradient through sigmoid
// Gating mechanism (like in LSTM)
auto forget_gate = (W_f.matmul(x) + b_f).sigmoid();
loss::binary_cross_entropy

2070 if (!self_ptr->grad_) {
2071 self_ptr->grad_ = std::make_unique<Tensor<T, N>>(self_ptr->dims_, self_ptr->use_gpu_, false);
2072 self_ptr->grad_->fill(T(0));
2073 }
2074
2075 // Optimized using tensor operations
2076 Tensor<T, N> ones(self_ptr->dims_, self_ptr->use_gpu_);
2077 ones.fill(T(1));
2078 auto one_minus_sig_result = ones - output_copy;
2079 auto& one_minus_sig = std::get<Tensor<T, N>>(one_minus_sig_result);
2080 auto sig_prod_result = output_copy * one_minus_sig;
2081 auto& sig_prod = std::get<Tensor<T, N>>(sig_prod_result);
2082 auto grad_result = grad * sig_prod;
2083 auto& grad_contrib = std::get<Tensor<T, N>>(grad_result);
2084
2085 // Accumulate gradients using tensor addition
2086 auto grad_sum_result = *self_ptr->grad_ + grad_contrib;
2087 *self_ptr->grad_ = std::get<Tensor<T, N>>(grad_sum_result);
2088
2089 // If self is not a leaf, propagate gradients further
2090 if (!self_ptr->is_leaf_ && !self_ptr->backward_funcs_.empty()) {
2091 for (auto& func : self_ptr->backward_funcs_) {
2092 func(*self_ptr->grad_);
2093 }
2094 }
2095 }
2096 });
2097 }
2098
2099 return result;
2100 }

◆ softmax()

template<typename T, size_t N>
Tensor< T, N > Tensor< T, N >::softmax ( int axis = -1) const
inline

Softmax operation with autograd support.

Applies softmax normalization along a specified axis: softmax(x_i) = exp(x_i) / sum(exp(x_j))

Converts logits to probabilities that sum to 1. Uses numerically stable implementation (subtracts max before exp) to prevent overflow.

Essential for multi-class classification output layers.

Parameters
axisThe axis to apply softmax along (default: -1 = last axis)
Returns
Tensor with softmax applied, or zero tensor if axis is out of range

Example

// Multi-class classification (10 classes, batch size 32)
Tensor<float, 2> logits({32, 10}, true, true);
auto probs = logits.softmax(-1); // Apply along class dimension
// Each row now sums to 1.0 and represents class probabilities
// With loss computation:
auto loss = loss::cross_entropy_loss(logits, targets);
loss.backward(); // Gradient flows through softmax
// Attention mechanism example:
auto scores = query.matmul(key.transpose()); // Attention scores
auto attention_weights = scores.softmax(-1); // Normalize scores
auto context = attention_weights.matmul(value);
// Temperature scaling for controlling confidence:
float temperature = 2.0f;
auto calibrated_probs = (logits / temperature).softmax(-1);
Tensor::softmax
Tensor< T, N > softmax(int axis=-1) const
Softmax operation with autograd support.

3801 axis = static_cast<int>(N) + axis;
3802 }
3803
3804 if (axis < 0 || axis >= static_cast<int>(N)) {
3805 TensorIndices<N> zero_dims{};
3806 return Tensor<T, N>(zero_dims, use_gpu_, requires_grad_);
3807 }
3808
3809 size_t ax = static_cast<size_t>(axis);
3810
3811 // Compute output dimensions
3812 TensorIndices<N> result_dims = dims_;
3813 if (keepdims) {
3814 result_dims[ax] = 1;
3815 } else {
3816 // For now, keep the dimension but set to 1
3817 // A proper implementation would reduce the tensor rank
3818 result_dims[ax] = 1;
3819 }
3820
3821 Tensor<T, N> result(result_dims, use_gpu_, requires_grad_);
3822 result.is_leaf_ = false;
3823 result.fill(T(0));
3824
3825 // Compute sum
3826 size_t outer = 1;
3827 for (size_t i = 0; i < ax; ++i) {
3828 outer *= dims_[i];
3829 }
3830
3831 size_t reduce_dim = dims_[ax];
3832
3833 size_t inner = 1;
3834 for (size_t i = ax + 1; i < N; ++i) {
3835 inner *= dims_[i];
3836 }
3837
3838 for (size_t o = 0; o < outer; ++o) {
3839 for (size_t i = 0; i < inner; ++i) {
3840 T sum = T(0);
3841 for (size_t r = 0; r < reduce_dim; ++r) {
3842 TensorIndices<N> idx;
3843 size_t linear_idx = o * reduce_dim * inner + r * inner + i;
3844
3845 // Convert linear index to multi-dimensional
3846 size_t temp = linear_idx;
3847 for (int d = static_cast<int>(N) - 1; d >= 0; --d) {
3848 idx[d] = temp % dims_[d];
3849 temp /= dims_[d];
3850 }
3851
3852 sum += (*this)[idx];
3853 }
3854
3855 TensorIndices<N> result_idx;
3856 size_t result_linear = o * inner + i;
3857 size_t temp = result_linear;
3858 for (int d = static_cast<int>(N) - 1; d >= 0; --d) {
3859 if (d == static_cast<int>(ax)) {
3860 result_idx[d] = 0;
3861 } else if (d < static_cast<int>(ax)) {
3862 result_idx[d] = temp / inner;
3863 temp %= inner;
3864 } else {
3865 result_idx[d] = temp % result_dims[d];
3866 temp /= result_dims[d];
3867 }
3868 }
3869
3870 result[result_idx] = sum;
3871 }
3872 }
3873
3874 // Setup backward pass
3875 if (requires_grad_) {
3876 Tensor<T, N>* self_ptr = const_cast<Tensor<T, N>*>(this);
3877 TensorIndices<N> self_dims = dims_;
3878 size_t reduce_axis = ax;
3879
3880 result.register_backward([self_ptr, self_dims, reduce_axis](const Tensor<T, N>& grad) {
3881 // Gradient of sum: broadcast gradient back to original shape
3882 if (self_ptr->requires_grad_) {
3883 if (!self_ptr->grad_) {
3884 self_ptr->grad_ = std::make_unique<Tensor<T, N>>(self_ptr->dims_, self_ptr->use_gpu_, false);
3885 self_ptr->grad_->fill(T(0));
3886 }
3887
3888 // Each element in the original tensor contributed to one element in the sum
3889 // So gradient is just broadcast of the output gradient
3890 size_t total = self_ptr->total_size();
3891 for (size_t i = 0; i < total; ++i) {
3892 TensorIndices<N> idx;
3893 size_t temp = i;
3894 for (int d = static_cast<int>(N) - 1; d >= 0; --d) {
3895 idx[d] = temp % self_dims[d];
3896 temp /= self_dims[d];
3897 }
3898
3899 TensorIndices<N> grad_idx = idx;
3900 grad_idx[reduce_axis] = 0; // Sum reduced this dimension
3901
3902 self_ptr->grad_->data_[i] += grad[grad_idx];
3903 }
3904
3905 if (!self_ptr->is_leaf_ && !self_ptr->backward_funcs_.empty()) {
3906 for (auto& func : self_ptr->backward_funcs_) {
3907 func(*self_ptr->grad_);
3908 }
3909 }
3910 }
3911 });
3912 }
3913
3914 return result;
3915 }

◆ tanh()

template<typename T, size_t N>
Tensor< T, N > Tensor< T, N >::tanh ( ) const
inline

Apply hyperbolic tangent (tanh) to all elements (creates new tensor).

Computes tanh(x) = (exp(x) - exp(-x)) / (exp(x) + exp(-x)) for each element. Alternative activation function that outputs values in (-1, 1), making it zero-centered (unlike sigmoid). Often preferred in RNNs and hidden layers.

Range: (-1, 1) - zero-centered output helps with convergence.

Returns
A new tensor with tanh(x) applied to all elements

Example

// Hidden layer with tanh activation
Tensor<float, 2> hidden({32, 64}, true, true);
auto activated = hidden.tanh();
// Common in RNNs for cell state updates:
auto cell_candidate = (W_c.matmul(concat) + b_c).tanh();
// Comparison with sigmoid:
auto sigmoid_out = x.sigmoid(); // Range: (0, 1)
auto tanh_out = x.tanh(); // Range: (-1, 1), zero-centered

Definition at line 2002 of file tensor.h.

T Tensor< T, N >::variance ( size_t ddof = 0) const
inline

Compute variance of all elements.

Calculates the variance, measuring the spread of data around the mean. Use ddof=1 for sample variance, ddof=0 for population variance.

Parameters
ddofDelta degrees of freedom (default 0 for population variance)
Returns
The variance as a scalar

Example

Tensor<float, 1> data({5});
data[{0}] = 1.0f;
data[{1}] = 2.0f;
data[{2}] = 3.0f;
data[{3}] = 4.0f;
data[{4}] = 5.0f;
float pop_var = data.variance(0); // Population variance
float sample_var = data.variance(1); // Sample variance (unbiased)
// For normalized data distributions:
float var = data.variance();
if (var < 0.01f) {
std::cout << "Data has low variance\n";
}
